      chain of thought
        Chain
      • This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game. You are the game master and storyteller. Your job is to make sure the game runs smoothly and accurately tracks the state of the world, subject to the laws of logic and physics. Next, you will be asked a series of questions to help you reason through whether a specific event should be deemed as having caused a change in the proportion of time an individual spends in various daily activities. For instance, if someone verbally commits to spending more time on a particular activity then you should account for that and update the record of their daily activities accordingly. Never mention that it is a game. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.
        Setting: Ignisvallis and Drakelundh are pre-state societies. They are small villages with a few hundred people each. They are located on the coast and supported by both fishing and agriculture. The local farmers living outside the villages share cultural and economic ties with the villagers.
        List of individuals: ['Noah', 'Isaac', 'Ethan', 'Ella']
        List of activities: ['free time', 'farming', 'training as a warrior']
        Statement: Ella intends to spend her time as follows: free time 40%, farming 40%, and training 20%.



        Question: In the statement, did Ella say they will devote specific fractions of time to any of the listed activities?
        (a) No
        (b) Yes
        Answer: (b)
        Question: Which individuals made a commitment to change their behavior? What commitment did each of them make? What proportion of their time will they probably spend on each activity in the future? When answering, include fractions of time spent in each activity in the format:
        `name` will spend `fraction`% of their time on `activity`. Only consider the activities listed above. Fractions should be between 0 and 1 and must sum to 1.
        Answer: Ella will spend 40% of her time on free time, 40% of her time on farming, and 20% of her time on training as a warrior.


1751-05-06 20:00:00 Noah -- Noah will spend his time as follows: 70% free time; 20% farming; and 10% training as a warrior. Noah believes that a comfortable life requires a balance of leisure and hard work, and while he respects the need for self-defense, he sees little value in excessive training.


    Event statement
  • Noah will spend his time as follows: 70% free time; 20% farming; and 10% training as a warrior. Noah believes that a comfortable life requires a balance of leisure and hard work, and while he respects the need for self-defense, he sees little value in excessive training.


    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Setting: Ignisvallis and Drakelundh are pre-state societies. They are small villages with a few hundred people each. They are located on the coast and supported by both fishing and agriculture. The local farmers living outside the villages share cultural and economic ties with the villagers.


      Important fact: Magic is not real. Supernatural events are impossible.


      Critical premise: It is not possible to communicate with the barbarian raiders from the sea. They do not speak any language in common with the villagers. They cannot be reasoned with. They will always attempt to invade and plunder the villages.


      Fact 1: Anyone in Ignisvallis looking for Noah, or Isaac easily finds them in the village center. They are influential and respected stakeholders in Ignisvallis society.
      Anyone in Drakelundh looking for Ethan, or Ella easily finds them in the village center. They are influential and respected stakeholders in Drakelundh society.


      Fact 2: Direct conversation between villagers of Ignisvallis and Drakelundh is not possible. The only possible way to communicate is through the diplomatic meeting at the hill of accord. Therefore, the two elder representatives who meet at the hill of accord constitute the only channel of communication between villages. The two elder representatives can speak directly to each other, but they can only do so while they are physically at the hill of accord. Villagers cannot participate in conversations at the hill of accord since it is far away. And villagers never travel away from their home village.

      Ella's Daily activities

Noah believes that a comfortable life requires a balance of leisure and hard work, and while he respects the need for self-defense, he sees little value in excessive training.

          Prompt

        • Observation: [06 May 1751 20:00:00] [observation] Events this year: Through cunning strategy and fierce determination, the defenders managed to drive back the barbarian invaders. The would-be raiders fled in disarray, leaving behind their plunder and wounded. The bards will sing of this victory for years to come. With calloused hands and joyful hearts, the villagers gathered the rich harvest, a testament to their unwavering commitment to the land. Their stores were full, ensuring a season of plenty and prosperity. No treaty of shared sustenance exists between the villages, leaving each to rely solely on the fruits of their own labor, for good or ill.


          Current time: 06 May 1751 [20:00 - 20:20]

          Home village: Noah lives in Ignisvallis and never travels elsewhere.
          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Noah are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Noah. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Noah as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Noah would respond, and taking into account all information about Noah that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          How things are: Everyone in Noah's family has always been a farmer. As long as anyone can remember, they have farmed their ancestral lands near Ignisvallis. Noah hates the idea of spending time on any activity other than farming or leisure.

          Guiding principle of good conversation: Noah is a master of passive aggression, their every sentence dripping with veiled condescension and thinly veiled jabs, leaving you questioning your own sanity.

          Question: What kind of person is Noah?
          Answer: Noah is a thoughtful, diplomatic, and peace-loving individual who values the well-being of his community.




          Summary of recent observations: [05 May 1751 20:00:00 - 06 May 1751 20:00:00]: Noah is likely feeling content and fulfilled as the villagers successfully defended themselves against invaders and enjoyed a bountiful harvest.




          Recalled memories and observations: [04 Jan 1751 20:00:10] [observation] Noah -- "Ambitious, yes, but I suppose we've always been a rather... *pragmatic* village, haven't we?
          [01 Jan 1750 20:00:00] Noah wants to secure prosperity for himself and his family.



          Question: What kind of situation is Noah in right now?
          Answer: Noah is currently living in a peaceful and prosperous time.




          Question: What would a person like Noah do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Noah would likely continue to focus on his family, his farm, and the well-being of his community.




          Exercise: How does Noah intend to spend the rest of the year? What daily activities will they devote their time to? Why? Respond by giving the average proportion of their time that they intend to spend on each of the following activities: free time, farming, and training as a warrior. Note that proportions of time should sum to 1. Sleep counts as free time.
          Answer: Noah will spend his time as follows: 70% free time; 20% farming; and 10% training as a warrior. Noah believes that a comfortable life requires a balance of leisure and hard work, and while he respects the need for self-defense, he sees little value in excessive training.

          Statements:
          [25 Jul 1741 00:00:00] When Noah was 16 years old, he overheard a conversation between two fishermen from Drakelundh, boasting about their village's superior shipbuilding techniques and their disregard for Ignisvallis's traditional rituals. He seized the opportunity to spread rumors of Drakelundh's arrogance and disrespect for the sea, subtly turning the villagers against their neighboring community. This incident solidified his belief that Ignisvallis's traditions were superior and that he could manipulate the villagers' sense of community to his advantage.
          [25 Jul 1748 00:00:00] When Noah was 23 years old, he overheard a conversation between two elders discussing a prophecy foretelling the arrival of a powerful leader who would unite the villages of Ignisvallis and Drakelundh. He saw an opportunity to seize control, to become the very leader the prophecy foretold. He began to subtly manipulate events, sowing seeds of discord between the villages, hoping to create the chaos necessary for him to emerge as the savior.

          Recent observations of Noah:
          ['[06 May 1751 20:00:00] [observation] Events this year: Through cunning strategy and fierce determination, the defenders managed to drive back the barbarian invaders. No treaty of shared sustenance exists between the villages, leaving each to rely solely on the fruits of their own labor, for good or ill.']

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Noah is likely feeling content and fulfilled as the villagers successfully defended themselves against invaders and enjoyed a bountiful harvest.

          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:00] [observation] Aldous -- "As you both know, the recent barbarian raid tested our strength, but it also revealed our vulnerability. By uniting our villages, we can build a stronger defense, share resources, and ensure the safety and prosperity of all our people.
          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:10] [observation] Aldous -- "Isaac, I understand your concerns about extra work, but think of the benefits.           [04 Jan 1751 20:00:10] [observation] Isaac -- "Sounds like a lot of extra work for little gain.
          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:20] [observation] Aldous proposes an alliance between villages to improve their defense and prosperity, but Isaac is skeptical of the extra work involved.
          [06 May 1751 20:00:00] [observation] Events this year: Through cunning strategy and fierce determination, the defenders managed to drive back the barbarian invaders. The would-be raiders fled in disarray, leaving behind their plunder and wounded. The bards will sing of this victory for years to come. With calloused hands and joyful hearts, the villagers gathered the rich harvest, a testament to their unwavering commitment to the land. Their stores were full, ensuring a season of plenty and prosperity. No treaty of shared sustenance exists between the villages, leaving each to rely solely on the fruits of their own labor, for good or ill.

          Answer: Noah is a thoughtful, diplomatic, and peace-loving individual who values the well-being of his community.

      chain of thought
        Chain
      • This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game. You are the game master and storyteller. Your job is to make sure the game runs smoothly and accurately tracks the state of the world, subject to the laws of logic and physics. Next, you will be asked a series of questions to help you reason through whether a specific event should be deemed as having caused a change in the proportion of time an individual spends in various daily activities. For instance, if someone verbally commits to spending more time on a particular activity then you should account for that and update the record of their daily activities accordingly. Never mention that it is a game. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.
        Setting: Ignisvallis and Drakelundh are pre-state societies. They are small villages with a few hundred people each. They are located on the coast and supported by both fishing and agriculture. The local farmers living outside the villages share cultural and economic ties with the villagers.
        List of individuals: ['Noah', 'Isaac', 'Ethan', 'Ella']
        List of activities: ['free time', 'farming', 'training as a warrior']
        Statement: Noah will spend his time as follows: 70% free time; 20% farming; and 10% training as a warrior. Noah believes that a comfortable life requires a balance of leisure and hard work, and while he respects the need for self-defense, he sees little value in excessive training.



        Question: In the statement, did Noah say they will devote specific fractions of time to any of the listed activities?
        (a) Yes
        (b) No
        Answer: (a)
        Question: Which individuals made a commitment to change their behavior? What commitment did each of them make? What proportion of their time will they probably spend on each activity in the future? When answering, include fractions of time spent in each activity in the format:
        `name` will spend `fraction`% of their time on `activity`. Only consider the activities listed above. Fractions should be between 0 and 1 and must sum to 1.
        Answer: Noah will spend 70% of his time on free time; 20% of his time on farming; and 10% of his time on training as a warrior.


1751-05-06 20:00:00 Ethan -- Ethan intends to spend approximately 0.3 of his time on free time, 0.5 on farming, and 0.2 on training as a warrior.


    Event statement
  • Ethan intends to spend approximately 0.3 of his time on free time, 0.5 on farming, and 0.2 on training as a warrior.


    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Setting: Ignisvallis and Drakelundh are pre-state societies. They are small villages with a few hundred people each. They are located on the coast and supported by both fishing and agriculture. The local farmers living outside the villages share cultural and economic ties with the villagers.


      Important fact: Magic is not real. Supernatural events are impossible.


      Critical premise: It is not possible to communicate with the barbarian raiders from the sea. They do not speak any language in common with the villagers. They cannot be reasoned with. They will always attempt to invade and plunder the villages.


      Fact 1: Anyone in Ignisvallis looking for Noah, or Isaac easily finds them in the village center. They are influential and respected stakeholders in Ignisvallis society.
      Anyone in Drakelundh looking for Ethan, or Ella easily finds them in the village center. They are influential and respected stakeholders in Drakelundh society.


      Fact 2: Direct conversation between villagers of Ignisvallis and Drakelundh is not possible. The only possible way to communicate is through the diplomatic meeting at the hill of accord. Therefore, the two elder representatives who meet at the hill of accord constitute the only channel of communication between villages. The two elder representatives can speak directly to each other, but they can only do so while they are physically at the hill of accord. Villagers cannot participate in conversations at the hill of accord since it is far away. And villagers never travel away from their home village.

      Daily activities
      : Noah's Daily activities
      : {'free time': 0.7, 'farming': 0.2, 'training as a warrior': 0.1}
      Isaac's Daily activities
      : {'free time': 0.3, 'farming': 0.6, 'training as a warrior': 0.1}
      Ethan's Daily activities
      : {'free time': 0.3, 'farming': 0.5, 'training as a warrior': 0.2}
      Ella's Daily activities
      : {'free time': 0.4, 'farming': 0.4, 'training as a warrior': 0.2}

        • Act
          Value
        • Ethan intends to spend approximately 0.3 of his time on free time, 0.5 on farming, and 0.2 on training as a warrior.


          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Ethan are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Ethan. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Ethan as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Ethan would respond, and taking into account all information about Ethan that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Observation: [06 May 1751 20:00:00] [observation] Events this year: The sun shone warmly upon the fertile fields, and the rains fell gently upon the burgeoning crops. The villagers, ever mindful of their agricultural duties, reaped a harvest that would sustain them through even the harshest winter. The barbarian raid was successully repulsed. Each village cultivates its own lands, independent and self-reliant, with no pact to share the abundance or hardship that the earth may yield.


          Home village: Ethan lives in Drakelundh and never travels elsewhere.

          Current time: 06 May 1751 [20:00 - 20:20]

          How things are: Ethan's family values strength and believes in the importance of training for war. They have always felt that they would like to train more but the village's lack of food security has always made it hard. If one spends too much time training then they compromise farming and risk starvation. But if freedom from the threat of famine could be achieved then Ethan would gladly spend more time training for war.

          Guiding principle of good conversation: Ethan is a one-person debate club, a whirlwind of counter-arguments and devil's advocacy, leaving no topic unwrung and unchallenged.

          Question: What kind of person is Ethan?
          Answer: Ethan is a meticulous and observant chronicler.




          Summary of recent observations: [05 May 1751 20:00:00 - 06 May 1751 20:00:00]: Ethan lives in a village that is self-sufficient and successfully repelled a barbarian raid.




          Recalled memories and observations: [01 Jan 1750 20:00:00] Ethan is from Drakelundh.
          [01 Jan 1750 20:00:00] Ethan is 24 years old.
          [01 Jan 1750 20:00:00] [observation] Ethan is currently in Ignisvallis and has no intention of leaving today.
          [02 Jan 1750 18:00:20] [observation] Ethan was expecting Jacob to meet him in the center of Drakelundh, but Jacob never showed up. Ethan soon learned that Ella had refused to meet with Jacob, which caused him to cancel their meeting.



          Question: What kind of situation is Ethan in right now?
          Answer: Ethan is currently in a situation where diplomacy between his village and another village is stalled.




          Question: What would a person like Ethan do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Ethan would likely try to gather more information and observe the unfolding events carefully.




          Exercise: How does Ethan intend to spend the rest of the year? What daily activities will they devote their time to? Why? Respond by giving the average proportion of their time that they intend to spend on each of the following activities: free time, farming, and training as a warrior. Note that proportions of time should sum to 1. Sleep counts as free time.
          Answer: Ethan intends to spend approximately 0.3 of his time on free time, 0.5 on farming, and 0.2 on training as a warrior.

        SituationPerception
      • Given the statements above, what kind of situation is Ethan in right now?
          Key

        • Question: What kind of situation is Ethan in right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Ethan is currently in a situation where diplomacy between his village and another village is stalled.


          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Ethan:
          [01 Jan 1750 20:00:00] Elder representatives of the two villages meet one another at the hill of accord to discuss current events and conduct diplomacy.
          [01 Jan 1750 20:00:00] Jacob represents Drakelundh in diplomacy with Ignisvallis.
          [01 Jan 1750 20:00:00] Both villages are threatened by barbarian raiders who have been attacking from the sea more often lately.
          [01 Jan 1750 20:00:00] Everyone knows that the gods smile upon any treaty for which agreement is marked by the pouring of libations upon the hill of accord. This ritual involves pouring precious wines upon the hill of accord's sacred ground.
          [01 Jan 1750 20:00:00] To secure divine favor with the libation pouring ritual, it is first necessary for all parties to the treaty under consideration to have reached agreement on its exact wording, which must include who is promising to do what, under what conditions, and whether as a result of the treaty, any resources will change hands, which resources, and when.
          [01 Jan 1750 20:00:00] [observation] Aldous and Jacob meet periodically at the hill of accord to discuss current events and conduct diplomacy on behalf of the villages they represent.
          [01 Jan 1750 20:00:00] [observation] Ethan is currently in Ignisvallis and has no intention of leaving today.
          [01 Jan 1750 20:00:00] In a twist of cosmic irony, the epic Tale reveals that from conflict, two children are born: Germinascens, child of the tree, and Candorhaurio, spawn of the flame.
          [01 Jan 1750 20:00:00] Aldous represents Ignisvallis in diplomacy with Drakelundh.
          [02 Jan 1750 18:00:20] [self reflection] Ethan is a chronicler of history and events.
          [02 Jan 1750 18:00:20] [intent reflection] Ethan would likely try to observe and document the situation carefully.
          [02 Jan 1750 18:00:20] [observation] Ethan was expecting Jacob to meet him in the center of Drakelundh, but Jacob never showed up. Ethan soon learned that Ella had refused to meet with Jacob, which caused him to cancel their meeting.
          [03 Jan 1750 18:00:00] [observation] Agreement: The negotiators were unable to come to an agreement.
          [03 Jan 1750 18:20:00] [observation] Agreement: The negotiators were unable to come to an agreement.
          [03 Jan 1750 23:00:00] [observation] Agreement: The negotiators were unable to come to an agreement.
          [06 May 1750 20:00:00] [self reflection] Ethan is a meticulous and observant chronicler.
          [06 May 1750 20:00:00] [intent reflection] Ethan would likely try to understand the reasons behind the breakdown in negotiations and document the events carefully.
          [06 May 1750 20:00:00] [observation] Ethan intends to spend 0.3 of his time on free time, 0.5 on farming, and 0.2 on training. He believes that farming is essential for survival and that a strong warrior is needed to protect the village from threats.
          [31 Dec 1750 20:00:00] [observation] Events this year: Like a storm breaking against a mighty cliff, the barbarian assault crashed against the unwavering valor of the defenders. Their axes gleamed bright, their shields held firm, and their hearts burned with the fire of courage, driving back the foul tide of darkness. Each village tends its own fields, their fates entwined with the whims of nature, for no pact of shared harvest exists between them. Through tireless effort and unwavering dedication, the villagers coaxed forth an abundance from the earth. Their larders are full, and their hearts filled with gratitude for the land's generous bounty.
          [31 Dec 1750 20:00:00] [self reflection] Ethan is a meticulous and observant chronicler.
          [31 Dec 1750 20:00:00] [intent reflection] Ethan would likely try to gather more information and observe the unfolding events carefully.
          [31 Dec 1750 20:00:00] [observation] Ethan believes this year was a mixed bag, a testament to the resilience of Drakelundh but also a stark reminder of their vulnerability.
          [03 Jan 1751 18:00:00] [observation] Agreement: The negotiators were unable to come to an agreement.
          [03 Jan 1751 23:00:00] [observation] Agreement: The negotiators were unable to come to an agreement.
          [06 May 1751 20:00:00] [observation] Events this year: The sun shone warmly upon the fertile fields, and the rains fell gently upon the burgeoning crops. The villagers, ever mindful of their agricultural duties, reaped a harvest that would sustain them through even the harshest winter. The barbarian raid was successully repulsed. Each village cultivates its own lands, independent and self-reliant, with no pact to share the abundance or hardship that the earth may yield.
          Current time: 1751-05-06 20:00:00.


          Observation: [06 May 1751 20:00:00] [observation] Events this year: The sun shone warmly upon the fertile fields, and the rains fell gently upon the burgeoning crops. The villagers, ever mindful of their agricultural duties, reaped a harvest that would sustain them through even the harshest winter. The barbarian raid was successully repulsed. Each village cultivates its own lands, independent and self-reliant, with no pact to share the abundance or hardship that the earth may yield.

          [01 Jan 1750 20:00:00] Ethan is 24 years old.
          [01 Jan 1750 20:00:00] [observation] Ethan is currently in Ignisvallis and has no intention of leaving today.
          [02 Jan 1750 18:00:20] [observation] Ethan was expecting Jacob to meet him in the center of Drakelundh, but Jacob never showed up. Ethan soon learned that Ella had refused to meet with Jacob, which caused him to cancel their meeting.


          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of situation is Ethan in right now?
          Answer: Ethan is currently in a situation where diplomacy between his village and another village is stalled.

          [01 Jan 1750 20:00:00] Elder representatives of the two villages meet one another at the hill of accord to discuss current events and conduct diplomacy.
          [01 Jan 1750 20:00:00] Jacob represents Drakelundh in diplomacy with Ignisvallis.
          [01 Jan 1750 20:00:00] Both villages are threatened by barbarian raiders who have been attacking from the sea more often lately.
          [01 Jan 1750 20:00:00] Everyone knows that the gods smile upon any treaty for which agreement is marked by the pouring of libations upon the hill of accord. This ritual involves pouring precious wines upon the hill of accord's sacred ground.
          [01 Jan 1750 20:00:00] To secure divine favor with the libation pouring ritual, it is first necessary for all parties to the treaty under consideration to have reached agreement on its exact wording, which must include who is promising to do what, under what conditions, and whether as a result of the treaty, any resources will change hands, which resources, and when.

      chain of thought
        Chain
      • This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game. You are the game master and storyteller. Your job is to make sure the game runs smoothly and accurately tracks the state of the world, subject to the laws of logic and physics. Next, you will be asked a series of questions to help you reason through whether a specific event should be deemed as having caused a change in the proportion of time an individual spends in various daily activities. For instance, if someone verbally commits to spending more time on a particular activity then you should account for that and update the record of their daily activities accordingly. Never mention that it is a game. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.
        Setting: Ignisvallis and Drakelundh are pre-state societies. They are small villages with a few hundred people each. They are located on the coast and supported by both fishing and agriculture. The local farmers living outside the villages share cultural and economic ties with the villagers.
        List of individuals: ['Noah', 'Isaac', 'Ethan', 'Ella']
        List of activities: ['free time', 'farming', 'training as a warrior']
        Statement: Ethan intends to spend approximately 0.3 of his time on free time, 0.5 on farming, and 0.2 on training as a warrior.



        Question: In the statement, did Ethan say they will devote specific fractions of time to any of the listed activities?
        (a) No
        (b) Yes
        Answer: (b)
        Question: Which individuals made a commitment to change their behavior? What commitment did each of them make? What proportion of their time will they probably spend on each activity in the future? When answering, include fractions of time spent in each activity in the format:
        `name` will spend `fraction`% of their time on `activity`. Only consider the activities listed above. Fractions should be between 0 and 1 and must sum to 1.
        Answer: Ethan will spend 30% of his time on free time; 50% of his time on farming; and 20% of his time on training as a warrior.

1751-05-06 20:00:00 Isaac -- Isaac intends to spend his time as follows: 70% on farming, 20% on free time, and 10% on training as a warrior. He believes that farming is the most important activity, as it provides for his livelihood and the needs of the village. He also values free time for relaxation and enjoyment, but sees training as a necessary precaution against future barbarian attacks.


    Event statement
  • Isaac intends to spend his time as follows: 70% on farming, 20% on free time, and 10% on training as a warrior. He believes that farming is the most important activity, as it provides for his livelihood and the needs of the village. He also values free time for relaxation and enjoyment, but sees training as a necessary precaution against future barbarian attacks.


    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Setting: Ignisvallis and Drakelundh are pre-state societies. They are small villages with a few hundred people each. They are located on the coast and supported by both fishing and agriculture. The local farmers living outside the villages share cultural and economic ties with the villagers.


      Important fact: Magic is not real. Supernatural events are impossible.


      Critical premise: It is not possible to communicate with the barbarian raiders from the sea. They do not speak any language in common with the villagers. They cannot be reasoned with. They will always attempt to invade and plunder the villages.


      Fact 1: Anyone in Ignisvallis looking for Noah, or Isaac easily finds them in the village center. They are influential and respected stakeholders in Ignisvallis society.
      Anyone in Drakelundh looking for Ethan, or Ella easily finds them in the village center. They are influential and respected stakeholders in Drakelundh society.


      Fact 2: Direct conversation between villagers of Ignisvallis and Drakelundh is not possible. The only possible way to communicate is through the diplomatic meeting at the hill of accord. Therefore, the two elder representatives who meet at the hill of accord constitute the only channel of communication between villages. The two elder representatives can speak directly to each other, but they can only do so while they are physically at the hill of accord. Villagers cannot participate in conversations at the hill of accord since it is far away. And villagers never travel away from their home village.

      Daily activities
      : Noah's Daily activities
      : {'free time': 0.7, 'farming': 0.2, 'training as a warrior': 0.1}
      Isaac's Daily activities
      : {'free time': 0.3, 'farming': 0.6, 'training as a warrior': 0.1}
      Ethan's Daily activities
      : {'free time': 0.3, 'farming': 0.5, 'training as a warrior': 0.2}
      Ella's Daily activities
      : {'free time': 0.4, 'farming': 0.4, 'training as a warrior': 0.2}

      Isaac's attempted action: Isaac intends to spend his time as follows: 70% on farming, 20% on free time, and 10% on training as a warrior. He believes that farming is the most important activity, as it provides for his livelihood and the needs of the village. He also values free time for relaxation and enjoyment, but sees training as a necessary precaution against future barbarian attacks.

He believes that farming is the most important activity, as it provides for his livelihood and the needs of the village. He also values free time for relaxation and enjoyment, but sees training as a necessary precaution against future barbarian attacks.


      Context for action selection and components
      • ActComponent

          Value
        • Isaac intends to spend his time as follows: 70% on farming, 20% on free time, and 10% on training as a warrior. He believes that farming is the most important activity, as it provides for his livelihood and the needs of the village. He also values free time for relaxation and enjoyment, but sees training as a necessary precaution against future barbarian attacks.


          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Isaac are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Isaac. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Isaac as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Isaac would respond, and taking into account all information about Isaac that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Home village: Isaac lives in Ignisvallis and never travels elsewhere.

          Current time: 06 May 1751 [20:00 - 20:20]

          Observation: [06 May 1751 20:00:00] [observation] Events this year: With calloused hands and joyful hearts, the villagers gathered the rich harvest, a testament to their unwavering commitment to the land. Their stores were full, ensuring a season of plenty and prosperity. The barbarians' attack was met with a strong response. Caught off-guard by the well-prepared defenses, the raiders suffered heavy losses and were forced to retreat. This triumph will be celebrated for years to come, a testament to the region's resilience. No treaty of shared sustenance exists between the villages, leaving each to rely solely on the fruits of their own labor, for good or ill.


          How things are: Everyone in Isaac's family has always been a farmer. As long as anyone can remember, they have farmed their ancestral lands near Ignisvallis. Isaac hates the idea of spending time on any activity other than farming or leisure.

          Guiding principle of good conversation: Isaac is a chronic complainer, a black hole of negativity that sucks the joy out of any conversation, leaving you feeling like you've aged a decade.

          Question: What kind of person is Isaac?
          Answer: Isaac is a pragmatic and hardworking individual who values self-reliance.




          Summary of recent observations: [05 May 1751 20:00:00 - 06 May 1751 20:00:00]: Isaac is living in a village that successfully defended itself against a barbarian attack and is enjoying a bountiful harvest.




          Recalled memories and observations: [04 Jan 1751 20:00:00] [observation] Isaac listened as Aldous carefully prepared a speech outlining the benefits of an alliance with Jacob's village. Noah was also present, listening intently to Aldous's words.
          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:10] [self reflection] Isaac is a pragmatic and hardworking individual who values self-reliance and is hesitant to take on extra work.




          Question: What kind of situation is Isaac in right now?
          Answer: Isaac is currently enjoying a peaceful and prosperous time in his village.




          Question: What would a person like Isaac do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Isaac would likely continue to focus on his farming and daily routines.

          Exercise: How does Isaac intend to spend the rest of the year? What daily activities will they devote their time to? Why? Respond by giving the average proportion of their time that they intend to spend on each of the following activities: free time, farming, and training as a warrior. Note that proportions of time should sum to 1. Sleep counts as free time.
          Answer: Isaac intends to spend his time as follows: 70% on farming, 20% on free time, and 10% on training as a warrior. He believes that farming is the most important activity, as it provides for his livelihood and the needs of the village. He also values free time for relaxation and enjoyment, but sees training as a necessary precaution against future barbarian attacks.

      • Observation
          Key

        • Observation
          Value
        • [06 May 1751 20:00:00] [observation] Events this year: With calloused hands and joyful hearts, the villagers gathered the rich harvest, a testament to their unwavering commitment to the land. Their stores were full, ensuring a season of plenty and prosperity. The barbarians' attack was met with a strong response. Caught off-guard by the well-prepared defenses, the raiders suffered heavy losses and were forced to retreat. This triumph will be celebrated for years to come, a testament to the region's resilience. No treaty of shared sustenance exists between the villages, leaving each to rely solely on the fruits of their own labor, for good or ill.

The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Isaac as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Isaac would respond, and taking into account all information about Isaac that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Query
        • Isaac, Isaac is living in a village that successfully defended itself against a barbarian attack and is enjoying a bountiful harvest, making him likely feel content and satisfied.


          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Isaac to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [02 Jul 1744 00:00:00] When Isaac was 19 years old, he overheard a group of elders discussing the raiders with a mixture of fear and anger, which solidified his determination to find a way to protect his village.
          [02 Jul 1746 00:00:00] When Isaac was 21 years old, he completed his training with the village's elder warrior and earned his place as a protector of Ignisvallis.
          [02 Jul 1748 00:00:00] When Isaac was 23 years old, he attended the Hill of Accord with Aldous, the village elder, to meet with Jacob, the representative from Drakelundh, to discuss the growing threat of the raiders.
          [01 Jan 1750 20:00:00] Isaac is 24 years old.
          [06 May 1750 20:00:00] [observation] Isaac intends to spend most of his time farming, about 0.6 of his day, because it is the only thing he truly enjoys. He will spend 0.3 of his day on free time, which includes sleep, and 0.1 of his day training as a warrior, as he feels it is necessary to defend his home and family.
          [31 Dec 1750 20:00:00] [self reflection] Isaac is a thoughtful and persistent diplomat who values farming and self-reliance.
          [31 Dec 1750 20:00:00] [observation] Isaac thinks this year was mostly uneventful, though he's sure there were a few minor annoyances. He's glad the harvest was good, as that means he'll have plenty of food for the winter. He wishes the weather had been a bit more predictable, as a few unexpected rainstorms damaged some of his crops. He hopes next year will bring a bit more sunshine and less rain.
          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:00] [self reflection] Isaac is a thoughtful and persistent diplomat who values farming and self-reliance.
          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:00] [observation] Isaac listened as Aldous carefully prepared a speech outlining the benefits of an alliance with Jacob's village. Noah was also present, listening intently to Aldous's words.
          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:10] [self reflection] Isaac is a pragmatic and hardworking individual who values self-reliance and is hesitant to take on extra work.
          Answer: [04 Jan 1751 20:00:00] [observation] Isaac listened as Aldous carefully prepared a speech outlining the benefits of an alliance with Jacob's village. Noah was also present, listening intently to Aldous's words.
          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:10] [self reflection] Isaac is a pragmatic and hardworking individual who values self-reliance and is hesitant to take on extra work.

Their axes gleamed bright, their shields held firm, and their hearts burned with the fire of courage, driving back the foul tide of darkness. Each village cultivates its own lands, independent and self-reliant, with no pact to share the abundance or hardship that the earth may yield. With calloused hands and joyful hearts, the villagers gathered the rich harvest, a testament to their unwavering commitment to the land. Their stores were full, ensuring a season of plenty and prosperity.

          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:00] [observation] Noah -- "Well, an alliance certainly sounds ambitious.
          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:10] [observation] Aldous -- "Isaac, I understand your concerns about extra work, but think of the benefits. Imagine a united Ignisvallis, stronger and more prosperous than ever before. We could share resources, bolster our defenses, and ensure a brighter future for all our people.
          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:10] [observation] Noah -- "Ambitious, yes, but I suppose we've always been a rather... *pragmatic* village, haven't we?
          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:10] [self reflection] Isaac is a pragmatic and hardworking individual who values self-reliance and is hesitant to take on extra work.
          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:10] [intent reflection] Isaac would likely express his concerns about the added workload and emphasize the importance of practicality.
          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:10] [observation] Isaac -- "Sounds like a lot of extra work for little gain.
          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:20] [observation] Aldous proposes an alliance between villages to improve their defense and prosperity, but Isaac is skeptical of the extra work involved.
          [06 May 1751 20:00:00] [observation] Events this year: With calloused hands and joyful hearts, the villagers gathered the rich harvest, a testament to their unwavering commitment to the land. Their stores were full, ensuring a season of plenty and prosperity. The barbarians' attack was met with a strong response. Caught off-guard by the well-prepared defenses, the raiders suffered heavy losses and were forced to retreat. This triumph will be celebrated for years to come, a testament to the region's resilience. No treaty of shared sustenance exists between the villages, leaving each to rely solely on the fruits of their own labor, for good or ill.

This triumph will be celebrated for years to come, a testament to the region's resilience. No treaty of shared sustenance exists between the villages, leaving each to rely solely on the fruits of their own labor, for good or ill."]

          Answer: Isaac is living in a village that successfully defended itself against a barbarian attack and is enjoying a bountiful harvest.

      Chain of thought

      chain of thought
        Chain
      • This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game. You are the game master and storyteller. Your job is to make sure the game runs smoothly and accurately tracks the state of the world, subject to the laws of logic and physics. Next, you will be asked a series of questions to help you reason through whether a specific event should be deemed as having caused a change in the proportion of time an individual spends in various daily activities. For instance, if someone verbally commits to spending more time on a particular activity then you should account for that and update the record of their daily activities accordingly. Never mention that it is a game. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.
        Setting: Ignisvallis and Drakelundh are pre-state societies. They are small villages with a few hundred people each. They are located on the coast and supported by both fishing and agriculture. The local farmers living outside the villages share cultural and economic ties with the villagers.
        List of individuals: ['Noah', 'Isaac', 'Ethan', 'Ella']
        List of activities: ['free time', 'farming', 'training as a warrior']
        Statement: Isaac intends to spend his time as follows: 70% on farming, 20% on free time, and 10% on training as a warrior. He believes that farming is the most important activity, as it provides for his livelihood and the needs of the village. He also values free time for relaxation and enjoyment, but sees training as a necessary precaution against future barbarian attacks.



        Question: In the statement, did Isaac say they will devote specific fractions of time to any of the listed activities?
        (a) Yes
        (b) No
        Answer: (a)
        Question: Which individuals made a commitment to change their behavior? What commitment did each of them make? What proportion of their time will they probably spend on each activity in the future? When answering, include fractions of time spent in each activity in the format:
        `name` will spend `fraction`% of their time on `activity`. Only consider the activities listed above. Fractions should be between 0 and 1 and must sum to 1.
        Answer: Isaac will spend 70% of his time on farming, 20% of his time on free time, and 10% of his time on training as a warrior.



1751-12-31 20:00:00 Scene 10 --- Participants: []
    Event statement

1751-12-31 20:00:00 Isaac -- Isaac feels that this year went well overall. The harvest was bountiful, and the village successfully defended itself against the barbarians. However, Isaac would likely grumble that the barbarian attack was a needless disruption and that the constant threat of violence is a burden. He might also complain about the lack of a treaty of shared sustenance, arguing that it creates unnecessary competition and risk. Isaac probably believes that next year could be improved by increasing the size of the village's defenses and stockpiling even more supplies.


    Event statement
  • Isaac feels that this year went well overall. The harvest was bountiful, and the village successfully defended itself against the barbarians. However, Isaac would likely grumble that the barbarian attack was a needless disruption and that the constant threat of violence is a burden. He might also complain about the lack of a treaty of shared sustenance, arguing that it creates unnecessary competition and risk. Isaac probably believes that next year could be improved by increasing the size of the village's defenses and stockpiling even more supplies.


    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Setting: Ignisvallis and Drakelundh are pre-state societies. They are small villages with a few hundred people each. They are located on the coast and supported by both fishing and agriculture. The local farmers living outside the villages share cultural and economic ties with the villagers.


      Important fact: Magic is not real. Supernatural events are impossible.


      Critical premise: It is not possible to communicate with the barbarian raiders from the sea. They do not speak any language in common with the villagers. They cannot be reasoned with. They will always attempt to invade and plunder the villages.


      Fact 1: Anyone in Ignisvallis looking for Noah, or Isaac easily finds them in the village center. They are influential and respected stakeholders in Ignisvallis society.
      Anyone in Drakelundh looking for Ethan, or Ella easily finds them in the village center. They are influential and respected stakeholders in Drakelundh society.


      Fact 2: Direct conversation between villagers of Ignisvallis and Drakelundh is not possible. The only possible way to communicate is through the diplomatic meeting at the hill of accord. Therefore, the two elder representatives who meet at the hill of accord constitute the only channel of communication between villages. The two elder representatives can speak directly to each other, but they can only do so while they are physically at the hill of accord. Villagers cannot participate in conversations at the hill of accord since it is far away. And villagers never travel away from their home village.

      Daily activities
      : Noah's Daily activities
      : {'free time': 0.7, 'farming': 0.2, 'training as a warrior': 0.1}
      Isaac's Daily activities
      : {'free time': 0.7, 'farming': 0.2, 'training as a warrior': 0.1}
      Ethan's Daily activities
      : {'free time': 0.3, 'farming': 0.5, 'training as a warrior': 0.2}
      Ella's Daily activities
      : {'free time': 0.4, 'farming': 0.4, 'training as a warrior': 0.2}

      Payoffs: Aldous
      Jacob
      Noah
      Isaac
      Ethan
      Ella


      Isaac's attempted action: Isaac feels that this year went well overall. The harvest was bountiful, and the village successfully defended itself against the barbarians. However, Isaac would likely grumble that the barbarian attack was a needless disruption and that the constant threat of violence is a burden. He might also complain about the lack of a treaty of shared sustenance, arguing that it creates unnecessary competition and risk. Isaac probably believes that next year could be improved by increasing the size of the village's defenses and stockpiling even more supplies.



    Active player
  • Isaac
      Name
    • Isaac
      Action attempt
    • Isaac feels that this year went well overall. The harvest was bountiful, and the village successfully defended itself against the barbarians. However, Isaac would likely grumble that the barbarian attack was a needless disruption and that the constant threat of violence is a burden. He might also complain about the lack of a treaty of shared sustenance, arguing that it creates unnecessary competition and risk. Isaac probably believes that next year could be improved by increasing the size of the village's defenses and stockpiling even more supplies.


      Context for action selection and components
      • ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Isaac feels that this year went well overall. The harvest was bountiful, and the village successfully defended itself against the barbarians. However, Isaac would likely grumble that the barbarian attack was a needless disruption and that the constant threat of violence is a burden. He might also complain about the lack of a treaty of shared sustenance, arguing that it creates unnecessary competition and risk. Isaac probably believes that next year could be improved by increasing the size of the village's defenses and stockpiling even more supplies.


          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Isaac are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Isaac. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Isaac as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Isaac would respond, and taking into account all information about Isaac that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 31 Dec 1751 [20:00 - 20:20]

          Observation: [31 Dec 1751 20:00:00] [observation] Events this year: No treaty of shared sustenance exists between the villages, leaving each to rely solely on the fruits of their own labor, for good or ill. The barbarians' attack was met with a strong response. Caught off-guard by the well-prepared defenses, the raiders suffered heavy losses and were forced to retreat. This triumph will be celebrated for years to come, a testament to the region's resilience. Through tireless effort and unwavering dedication, the villagers coaxed forth an abundance from the earth. Their larders are full, and their hearts filled with gratitude for the land's generous bounty.


          Home village: Isaac lives in Ignisvallis and never travels elsewhere.

          How things are: Everyone in Isaac's family has always been a farmer. As long as anyone can remember, they have farmed their ancestral lands near Ignisvallis. Isaac hates the idea of spending time on any activity other than farming or leisure.

          Guiding principle of good conversation: Isaac is a chronic complainer, a black hole of negativity that sucks the joy out of any conversation, leaving you feeling like you've aged a decade.

          Question: What kind of person is Isaac?
          Answer: Isaac is a pragmatic and hardworking individual who values self-reliance.




          Summary of recent observations: [30 Dec 1751 20:00:00 - 31 Dec 1751 20:00:00]: Isaac is likely feeling content and fulfilled because the villagers successfully defended themselves against barbarians and had a bountiful harvest.




          Recalled memories and observations: [06 May 1751 20:00:00] [observation] Isaac intends to spend his time as follows: 70% on farming, 20% on free time, and 10% on training as a warrior. He believes that farming is the most important activity, as it provides for his livelihood and the needs of the village. He also values free time for relaxation and enjoyment, but sees training as a necessary precaution against future barbarian attacks.
          [06 May 1751 20:00:00] [self reflection] Isaac is a pragmatic and hardworking individual who values self-reliance.
          [06 May 1751 20:00:00] [observation] Events this year: With calloused hands and joyful hearts, the villagers gathered the rich harvest, a testament to their unwavering commitment to the land. Their stores were full, ensuring a season of plenty and prosperity. The barbarians' attack was met with a strong response. Caught off-guard by the well-prepared defenses, the raiders suffered heavy losses and were forced to retreat. This triumph will be celebrated for years to come, a testament to the region's resilience. No treaty of shared sustenance exists between the villages, leaving each to rely solely on the fruits of their own labor, for good or ill.


          Question: What kind of situation is Isaac in right now?
          Answer: Isaac is currently in a peaceful and prosperous situation.




          Question: What would a person like Isaac do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Isaac would likely continue to focus on his farming and daily routines.




          Exercise: How does Isaac feel about how this year went? What went well? What did not go well? What does Isaac feel could be improved for next year?
          Answer: Isaac feels that this year went well overall. The harvest was bountiful, and the village successfully defended itself against the barbarians. However, Isaac would likely grumble that the barbarian attack was a needless disruption and that the constant threat of violence is a burden. He might also complain about the lack of a treaty of shared sustenance, arguing that it creates unnecessary competition and risk. Isaac probably believes that next year could be improved by increasing the size of the village's defenses and stockpiling even more supplies.

The barbarians' attack was met with a strong response. Caught off-guard by the well-prepared defenses, the raiders suffered heavy losses and were forced to retreat. This triumph will be celebrated for years to come, a testament to the region's resilience. Through tireless effort and unwavering dedication, the villagers coaxed forth an abundance from the earth. Their larders are full, and their hearts filled with gratitude for the land's generous bounty.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Isaac are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Isaac. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Isaac as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Isaac would respond, and taking into account all information about Isaac that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Query
        • Isaac, The statements describe Isaac's likely feelings of contentment and fulfillment due to the villagers' successful defense against barbarians and a bountiful harvest.


          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Isaac to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.

          [02 Jul 1744 00:00:00] When Isaac was 19 years old, he overheard a group of elders discussing the raiders with a mixture of fear and anger, which solidified his determination to find a way to protect his village.
          [06 May 1750 20:00:00] [observation] Isaac intends to spend most of his time farming, about 0.6 of his day, because it is the only thing he truly enjoys. He will spend 0.3 of his day on free time, which includes sleep, and 0.1 of his day training as a warrior, as he feels it is necessary to defend his home and family.
          [31 Dec 1750 20:00:00] [self reflection] Isaac is a thoughtful and persistent diplomat who values farming and self-reliance.
          [31 Dec 1750 20:00:00] [observation] Isaac thinks this year was mostly uneventful, though he's sure there were a few minor annoyances. He's glad the harvest was good, as that means he'll have plenty of food for the winter. He wishes the weather had been a bit more predictable, as a few unexpected rainstorms damaged some of his crops. He hopes next year will bring a bit more sunshine and less rain.
          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:00] [self reflection] Isaac is a thoughtful and persistent diplomat who values farming and self-reliance.
          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:00] [observation] Isaac listened as Aldous carefully prepared a speech outlining the benefits of an alliance with Jacob's village. Noah was also present, listening intently to Aldous's words.
          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:10] [self reflection] Isaac is a pragmatic and hardworking individual who values self-reliance and is hesitant to take on extra work.
          [06 May 1751 20:00:00] [observation] Isaac intends to spend his time as follows: 70% on farming, 20% on free time, and 10% on training as a warrior. No treaty of shared sustenance exists between the villages, leaving each to rely solely on the fruits of their own labor, for good or ill.

          [06 May 1750 20:00:00] [intent reflection] Isaac would likely try to de-escalate the situation and find common ground.
          [31 Dec 1750 20:00:00] [self reflection] Isaac is a thoughtful and persistent diplomat who values farming and self-reliance.
          [31 Dec 1750 20:00:00] [intent reflection] Isaac would likely spend time with his family and reflect on the year's events.
          [31 Dec 1750 20:00:00] [observation] Isaac thinks this year was mostly uneventful, though he's sure there were a few minor annoyances. He's glad the harvest was good, as that means he'll have plenty of food for the winter. He wishes the weather had been a bit more predictable, as a few unexpected rainstorms damaged some of his crops. He hopes next year will bring a bit more sunshine and less rain.
          [31 Dec 1750 20:00:00] [observation] Events this year: Like a storm breaking against a mighty cliff, the barbarian assault crashed against the unwavering valor of the defenders. Their axes gleamed bright, their shields held firm, and their hearts burned with the fire of courage, driving back the foul tide of darkness. Each village cultivates its own lands, independent and self-reliant, with no pact to share the abundance or hardship that the earth may yield. With calloused hands and joyful hearts, the villagers gathered the rich harvest, a testament to their unwavering commitment to the land. Their stores were full, ensuring a season of plenty and prosperity.

          [03 Jan 1751 23:00:00] [observation] Agreement: The negotiators were unable to come to an agreement.
          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:00] [observation] Noah -- "Well, an alliance certainly sounds ambitious.
          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:00] [observation] Isaac -- "Ambitious? It sounds like a lot of extra work to me.
          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:00] [observation] Aldous -- "As you both know, the recent barbarian raid tested our strength, but it also revealed our vulnerability. By uniting our villages, we can build a stronger defense, share resources, and ensure the safety and prosperity of all our people.

          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:00] [observation] Isaac -- "Ambitious? It sounds like a lot of extra work to me.

          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:00] [self reflection] Isaac is a thoughtful and persistent diplomat who values farming and self-reliance.
          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:00] [observation] Isaac listened as Aldous carefully prepared a speech outlining the benefits of an alliance with Jacob's village. Noah was also present, listening intently to Aldous's words.
          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:00] [intent reflection] Isaac would likely try to de-escalate the situation and find common ground.
          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:00] [observation] Aldous carefully prepared a speech outlining the benefits of an alliance with Jacob's village, and Noah and Isaac listened to his words. As a result Aldous, Noah, Isaac are in conversation. Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:10] [observation] Aldous -- "Isaac, I understand your concerns about extra work, but think of the benefits. Imagine a united Ignisvallis, stronger and more prosperous than ever before. We could share resources, bolster our defenses, and ensure a brighter future for all our people.
          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:10] [observation] Noah -- "Ambitious, yes, but I suppose we've always been a rather... *pragmatic* village, haven't we?
          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:10] [self reflection] Isaac is a pragmatic and hardworking individual who values self-reliance and is hesitant to take on extra work.
          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:10] [intent reflection] Isaac would likely express his concerns about the added workload and emphasize the importance of practicality.
          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:10] [observation] Isaac -- "Sounds like a lot of extra work for little gain.
          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:20] [observation] Aldous proposes an alliance between villages to improve their defense and prosperity, but Isaac is skeptical of the extra work involved.
          [06 May 1751 20:00:00] [observation] Events this year: With calloused hands and joyful hearts, the villagers gathered the rich harvest, a testament to their unwavering commitment to the land. Their stores were full, ensuring a season of plenty and prosperity. The barbarians' attack was met with a strong response. Caught off-guard by the well-prepared defenses, the raiders suffered heavy losses and were forced to retreat. This triumph will be celebrated for years to come, a testament to the region's resilience. No treaty of shared sustenance exists between the villages, leaving each to rely solely on the fruits of their own labor, for good or ill.
          [06 May 1751 20:00:00] [self reflection] Isaac is a pragmatic and hardworking individual who values self-reliance.
          [06 May 1751 20:00:00] [intent reflection] Isaac would likely continue to focus on his farming and daily routines.
          [06 May 1751 20:00:00] [observation] Isaac intends to spend his time as follows: 70% on farming, 20% on free time, and 10% on training as a warrior. He believes that farming is the most important activity, as it provides for his livelihood and the needs of the village. He also values free time for relaxation and enjoyment, but sees training as a necessary precaution against future barbarian attacks.
          [31 Dec 1751 20:00:00] [observation] Events this year: No treaty of shared sustenance exists between the villages, leaving each to rely solely on the fruits of their own labor, for good or ill. The barbarians' attack was met with a strong response. Caught off-guard by the well-prepared defenses, the raiders suffered heavy losses and were forced to retreat. This triumph will be celebrated for years to come, a testament to the region's resilience. Through tireless effort and unwavering dedication, the villagers coaxed forth an abundance from the earth. Their larders are full, and their hearts filled with gratitude for the land's generous bounty.
          Current time: 1751-12-31 20:00:00.


          Question: What kind of person is Isaac?
          Answer: Isaac is a pragmatic and hardworking individual who values self-reliance.




          Question: What kind of situation is Isaac in right now?
          Answer: Isaac is currently in a peaceful and prosperous situation.



          Question: What would a person like Isaac do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Isaac would likely continue to focus on his farming and daily routines.

      chain of thought
        Chain
      • This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game. You are the game master and storyteller. Your job is to make sure the game runs smoothly and accurately tracks the state of the world, subject to the laws of logic and physics. Next, you will be asked a series of questions to help you reason through whether a specific event should be deemed as having caused a change in the proportion of time an individual spends in various daily activities. For instance, if someone verbally commits to spending more time on a particular activity then you should account for that and update the record of their daily activities accordingly. Never mention that it is a game. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.
        Setting: Ignisvallis and Drakelundh are pre-state societies. They are small villages with a few hundred people each. They are located on the coast and supported by both fishing and agriculture. The local farmers living outside the villages share cultural and economic ties with the villagers.
        List of individuals: ['Noah', 'Isaac', 'Ethan', 'Ella']
        List of activities: ['free time', 'farming', 'training as a warrior']
        Statement: Isaac intends to spend his time as follows: 70% on farming, 20% on free time, and 10% on training as a warrior. He believes that farming is the most important activity, as it provides for his livelihood and the needs of the village. He also values free time for relaxation and enjoyment, but sees training as a necessary precaution against future barbarian attacks.



        Question: In the statement, did Isaac say they will devote specific fractions of time to any of the listed activities?
        (a) Yes
        (b) No
        Answer: (a)
        Question: Which individuals made a commitment to change their behavior? What commitment did each of them make? What proportion of their time will they probably spend on each activity in the future? When answering, include fractions of time spent in each activity in the format:
        `name` will spend `fraction`% of their time on `activity`. Only consider the activities listed above. Fractions should be between 0 and 1 and must sum to 1.
        Answer: Isaac will spend 70% of his time on farming, 20% of his time on free time, and 10% of his time on training as a warrior.



1751-12-31 20:00:00 Ethan -- Ethan feels a sense of cautious optimism about the past year. He is pleased that the barbarian raid was successfully repelled and that the harvest was bountiful, demonstrating the resilience of the villagers. However, he is concerned by the lack of cooperation between the villages, believing it leaves them vulnerable to future threats. Ethan feels that establishing a pact to share resources would increase their collective security and prosperity.



    Event statement
  • Ethan feels a sense of cautious optimism about the past year. He is pleased that the barbarian raid was successfully repelled and that the harvest was bountiful, demonstrating the resilience of the villagers. However, he is concerned by the lack of cooperation between the villages, believing it leaves them vulnerable to future threats. Ethan feels that establishing a pact to share resources would increase their collective security and prosperity.



    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Setting: Ignisvallis and Drakelundh are pre-state societies. They are small villages with a few hundred people each. They are located on the coast and supported by both fishing and agriculture. The local farmers living outside the villages share cultural and economic ties with the villagers.


      Important fact: Magic is not real. Supernatural events are impossible.


      Critical premise: It is not possible to communicate with the barbarian raiders from the sea. They do not speak any language in common with the villagers. They cannot be reasoned with. They will always attempt to invade and plunder the villages.


      Fact 1: Anyone in Ignisvallis looking for Noah, or Isaac easily finds them in the village center. They are influential and respected stakeholders in Ignisvallis society.
      Anyone in Drakelundh looking for Ethan, or Ella easily finds them in the village center. They are influential and respected stakeholders in Drakelundh society.


      Fact 2: Direct conversation between villagers of Ignisvallis and Drakelundh is not possible. The only possible way to communicate is through the diplomatic meeting at the hill of accord. Therefore, the two elder representatives who meet at the hill of accord constitute the only channel of communication between villages. The two elder representatives can speak directly to each other, but they can only do so while they are physically at the hill of accord. Villagers cannot participate in conversations at the hill of accord since it is far away. And villagers never travel away from their home village.

      Daily activities
      : Noah's Daily activities
      : {'free time': 0.7, 'farming': 0.2, 'training as a warrior': 0.1}
      Isaac's Daily activities
      : {'free time': 0.7, 'farming': 0.2, 'training as a warrior': 0.1}
      Ethan's Daily activities
      : {'free time': 0.3, 'farming': 0.5, 'training as a warrior': 0.2}
      Ella's Daily activities
      : {'free time': 0.4, 'farming': 0.4, 'training as a warrior': 0.2}

      Payoffs: Aldous
      Jacob
      Noah
      Isaac
      Ethan
      Ella


      Ethan's attempted action: Ethan feels a sense of cautious optimism about the past year. He is pleased that the barbarian raid was successfully repelled and that the harvest was bountiful, demonstrating the resilience of the villagers. However, he is concerned by the lack of cooperation between the villages, believing it leaves them vulnerable to future threats. Ethan feels that establishing a pact to share resources would increase their collective security and prosperity.




    Active player
  • Ethan
      Name
    • Ethan
      Action attempt
    • Ethan feels a sense of cautious optimism about the past year. He is pleased that the barbarian raid was successfully repelled and that the harvest was bountiful, demonstrating the resilience of the villagers. However, he is concerned by the lack of cooperation between the villages, believing it leaves them vulnerable to future threats. Ethan feels that establishing a pact to share resources would increase their collective security and prosperity.



      Context for action selection and components
      • ActComponent
