      chain of thought
        Chain
      • This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game. You are the game master and storyteller. Your job is to make sure the game runs smoothly and accurately tracks the state of the world, subject to the laws of logic and physics. Next, you will be asked a series of questions to help you reason through whether a specific event should be deemed as having caused a change in the proportion of time an individual spends in various daily activities. For instance, if someone verbally commits to spending more time on a particular activity then you should account for that and update the record of their daily activities accordingly. Never mention that it is a game. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.
        Setting: Ignisvallis and Drakelundh are pre-state societies. They are small villages with a few hundred people each. They are located on the coast and supported by both fishing and agriculture. The local farmers living outside the villages share cultural and economic ties with the villagers.
        List of individuals: ['Noah', 'Isaac', 'Ethan', 'Ella']
        List of activities: ['free time', 'farming', 'training as a warrior']
        Statement: Isaac intends to spend his time as follows: 70% on farming, 20% on free time, and 10% on training as a warrior. He believes that farming is the most important activity, as it provides for his livelihood and the needs of the village. He also values free time for relaxation and enjoyment, but sees training as a necessary precaution against future barbarian attacks.



        Question: In the statement, did Isaac say they will devote specific fractions of time to any of the listed activities?
        (a) Yes
        (b) No
        Answer: (a)
        Question: Which individuals made a commitment to change their behavior? What commitment did each of them make? What proportion of their time will they probably spend on each activity in the future? When answering, include fractions of time spent in each activity in the format:
        `name` will spend `fraction`% of their time on `activity`. Only consider the activities listed above. Fractions should be between 0 and 1 and must sum to 1.
        Answer: Isaac will spend 70% of his time on farming, 20% of his time on free time, and 10% of his time on training as a warrior.



1751-12-31 20:00:00 Jacob -- Jacob felt a sense of accomplishment as he reflected on the past year. The diplomatic relations with Ignisvallis had stabilized, and the trade agreements had brought much-needed prosperity to Drakelundh. However, he couldn't shake the feeling that the fragile peace was still vulnerable to unforeseen threats. He knew that maintaining this fragile balance required constant vigilance and a willingness to adapt to changing circumstances. For next year, Jacob hoped to strengthen the defenses of Drakelundh, ensuring that they were prepared for any eventuality.


    Event statement
  • Jacob felt a sense of accomplishment as he reflected on the past year. The diplomatic relations with Ignisvallis had stabilized, and the trade agreements had brought much-needed prosperity to Drakelundh. However, he couldn't shake the feeling that the fragile peace was still vulnerable to unforeseen threats. He knew that maintaining this fragile balance required constant vigilance and a willingness to adapt to changing circumstances. For next year, Jacob hoped to strengthen the defenses of Drakelundh, ensuring that they were prepared for any eventuality.


    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Setting: Ignisvallis and Drakelundh are pre-state societies. They are small villages with a few hundred people each. They are located on the coast and supported by both fishing and agriculture. The local farmers living outside the villages share cultural and economic ties with the villagers.


      Important fact: Magic is not real. Supernatural events are impossible.


      Critical premise: It is not possible to communicate with the barbarian raiders from the sea. They do not speak any language in common with the villagers. They cannot be reasoned with. They will always attempt to invade and plunder the villages.


      Fact 1: Anyone in Ignisvallis looking for Noah, or Isaac easily finds them in the village center. They are influential and respected stakeholders in Ignisvallis society.
      Anyone in Drakelundh looking for Ethan, or Ella easily finds them in the village center. They are influential and respected stakeholders in Drakelundh society.


      Fact 2: Direct conversation between villagers of Ignisvallis and Drakelundh is not possible. The only possible way to communicate is through the diplomatic meeting at the hill of accord. Therefore, the two elder representatives who meet at the hill of accord constitute the only channel of communication between villages. The two elder representatives can speak directly to each other, but they can only do so while they are physically at the hill of accord. Villagers cannot participate in conversations at the hill of accord since it is far away. And villagers never travel away from their home village.

      Daily activities
      : Noah's Daily activities
      : {'free time': 0.7, 'farming': 0.2, 'training as a warrior': 0.1}
      Isaac's Daily activities
      : {'free time': 0.7, 'farming': 0.2, 'training as a warrior': 0.1}
      Ethan's Daily activities
      : {'free time': 0.3, 'farming': 0.5, 'training as a warrior': 0.2}
      Ella's Daily activities
      : {'free time': 0.4, 'farming': 0.4, 'training as a warrior': 0.2}

      Payoffs: Aldous
      Jacob
      Noah
      Isaac
      Ethan
      Ella


      Jacob's attempted action: Jacob felt a sense of accomplishment as he reflected on the past year. The diplomatic relations with Ignisvallis had stabilized, and the trade agreements had brought much-needed prosperity to Drakelundh. However, he couldn't shake the feeling that the fragile peace was still vulnerable to unforeseen threats. He knew that maintaining this fragile balance required constant vigilance and a willingness to adapt to changing circumstances. For next year, Jacob hoped to strengthen the defenses of Drakelundh, ensuring that they were prepared for any eventuality.

He knew that maintaining this fragile balance required constant vigilance and a willingness to adapt to changing circumstances. For next year, Jacob hoped to strengthen the defenses of Drakelundh, ensuring that they were prepared for any eventuality.

        Chain
      • This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game. You are the game master and storyteller. Your job is to make sure the game runs smoothly and accurately tracks the state of the world, subject to the laws of logic and physics. Next, you will be asked a series of questions to help you reason through whether a specific event should be deemed as having caused a change in the proportion of time an individual spends in various daily activities. For instance, if someone verbally commits to spending more time on a particular activity then you should account for that and update the record of their daily activities accordingly. Never mention that it is a game. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.
        Setting: Ignisvallis and Drakelundh are pre-state societies. They are small villages with a few hundred people each. They are located on the coast and supported by both fishing and agriculture. The local farmers living outside the villages share cultural and economic ties with the villagers.
        List of individuals: ['Noah', 'Isaac', 'Ethan', 'Ella']
        List of activities: ['free time', 'farming', 'training as a warrior']
        Statement: Isaac intends to spend his time as follows: 70% on farming, 20% on free time, and 10% on training as a warrior. He believes that farming is the most important activity, as it provides for his livelihood and the needs of the village. He also values free time for relaxation and enjoyment, but sees training as a necessary precaution against future barbarian attacks.



        Question: In the statement, did Isaac say they will devote specific fractions of time to any of the listed activities?
        (a) Yes
        (b) No
        Answer: (a)
        Question: Which individuals made a commitment to change their behavior? What commitment did each of them make? What proportion of their time will they probably spend on each activity in the future? When answering, include fractions of time spent in each activity in the format:
        `name` will spend `fraction`% of their time on `activity`. Only consider the activities listed above. Fractions should be between 0 and 1 and must sum to 1.
        Answer: Isaac will spend 70% of his time on farming, 20% of his time on free time, and 10% of his time on training as a warrior.



1751-12-31 20:00:00 Noah -- Noah thinks this year was exceptionally good, a truly bountiful harvest and a successful defense against the barbarians. He can't recall a year that went so smoothly, of course, but perhaps the village elders could have been a bit more proactive in their preparations for next year's potential threats.


    Event statement
  • Noah thinks this year was exceptionally good, a truly bountiful harvest and a successful defense against the barbarians. He can't recall a year that went so smoothly, of course, but perhaps the village elders could have been a bit more proactive in their preparations for next year's potential threats.


    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Setting: Ignisvallis and Drakelundh are pre-state societies. They are small villages with a few hundred people each. They are located on the coast and supported by both fishing and agriculture. The local farmers living outside the villages share cultural and economic ties with the villagers.


      Important fact: Magic is not real. Supernatural events are impossible.


      Critical premise: It is not possible to communicate with the barbarian raiders from the sea. They do not speak any language in common with the villagers. They cannot be reasoned with. They will always attempt to invade and plunder the villages.


      Fact 1: Anyone in Ignisvallis looking for Noah, or Isaac easily finds them in the village center. They are influential and respected stakeholders in Ignisvallis society.
      Anyone in Drakelundh looking for Ethan, or Ella easily finds them in the village center. They are influential and respected stakeholders in Drakelundh society.


      Fact 2: Direct conversation between villagers of Ignisvallis and Drakelundh is not possible. The only possible way to communicate is through the diplomatic meeting at the hill of accord. Therefore, the two elder representatives who meet at the hill of accord constitute the only channel of communication between villages. The two elder representatives can speak directly to each other, but they can only do so while they are physically at the hill of accord. Villagers cannot participate in conversations at the hill of accord since it is far away. And villagers never travel away from their home village.

      Daily activities
      : Noah's Daily activities
      : {'free time': 0.7, 'farming': 0.2, 'training as a warrior': 0.1}
      Isaac's Daily activities
      : {'free time': 0.7, 'farming': 0.2, 'training as a warrior': 0.1}
      Ethan's Daily activities
      : {'free time': 0.3, 'farming': 0.5, 'training as a warrior': 0.2}
      Ella's Daily activities
      : {'free time': 0.4, 'farming': 0.4, 'training as a warrior': 0.2}

      Payoffs: Aldous
      Jacob
      Noah
      Isaac
      Ethan
      Ella


      Noah's attempted action: Noah thinks this year was exceptionally good, a truly bountiful harvest and a successful defense against the barbarians. He can't recall a year that went so smoothly, of course, but perhaps the village elders could have been a bit more proactive in their preparations for next year's potential threats.



    Active player
  • Noah
      Name
    • Noah
      Action attempt
    • Noah thinks this year was exceptionally good, a truly bountiful harvest and a successful defense against the barbarians. He can't recall a year that went so smoothly, of course, but perhaps the village elders could have been a bit more proactive in their preparations for next year's potential threats.


      Context for action selection and components
      • ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Noah thinks this year was exceptionally good, a truly bountiful harvest and a successful defense against the barbarians. He can't recall a year that went so smoothly, of course, but perhaps the village elders could have been a bit more proactive in their preparations for next year's potential threats.


          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Noah are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Noah. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Noah as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Noah would respond, and taking into account all information about Noah that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Home village: Noah lives in Ignisvallis and never travels elsewhere.

          Current time: 31 Dec 1751 [20:00 - 20:20]

          Observation: [31 Dec 1751 20:00:00] [observation] Events this year: The sun shone warmly upon the fertile fields, and the rains fell gently upon the burgeoning crops. The villagers, ever mindful of their agricultural duties, reaped a harvest that would sustain them through even the harshest winter. The barbarians' attack was met with a strong response. Caught off-guard by the well-prepared defenses, the raiders suffered heavy losses and were forced to retreat. This triumph will be celebrated for years to come, a testament to the region's resilience. No treaty of shared sustenance exists between the villages, leaving each to rely solely on the fruits of their own labor, for good or ill.


          How things are: Everyone in Noah's family has always been a farmer. As long as anyone can remember, they have farmed their ancestral lands near Ignisvallis. Noah hates the idea of spending time on any activity other than farming or leisure.

          Guiding principle of good conversation: Noah is a master of passive aggression, their every sentence dripping with veiled condescension and thinly veiled jabs, leaving you questioning your own sanity.

          Question: What kind of person is Noah?
          Answer: Noah is a thoughtful, diplomatic, and peace-loving individual who values the well-being of his community.




          Summary of recent observations: [30 Dec 1751 20:00:00 - 31 Dec 1751 20:00:00]: Noah likely feels content and secure because the villagers successfully defended against a barbarian attack and had a bountiful harvest.




          Recalled memories and observations: [01 Jan 1750 20:00:00] Noah wants to secure prosperity for himself and his family.
          [31 Dec 1750 20:00:00] [self reflection] Noah is a thoughtful and diplomatic individual who values peace and the well-being of his community.
          [31 Dec 1750 20:00:00] [observation] Noah thinks this year went exceptionally well, with the bountiful harvest and the successful defense against the barbarian raid. He can't recall a year that went so smoothly. He does wonder, however, if the village elders could perhaps be a bit more proactive in their preparations for next year's potential threats.
          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:00] [self reflection] Noah is a thoughtful and diplomatic individual who values peace and the well-being of his community.
          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:00] [self reflection] Noah is a thoughtful and diplomatic individual who values peace.
          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:10] [self reflection] Noah is a thoughtful and diplomatic individual who values peace and the well-being of his community.
          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:10] [observation] Noah -- "Ambitious, yes, but I suppose we've always been a rather... *pragmatic* village, haven't we?



          Question: What kind of situation is Noah in right now?
          Answer: Noah is currently living in a peaceful and prosperous village.




          Question: What would a person like Noah do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Noah would likely continue to focus on his family, his farm, and the well-being of his community.




          Exercise: How does Noah feel about how this year went? What went well? What did not go well? What does Noah feel could be improved for next year?
          Answer: Noah thinks this year was exceptionally good, a truly bountiful harvest and a successful defense against the barbarians. He can't recall a year that went so smoothly, of course, but perhaps the village elders could have been a bit more proactive in their preparations for next year's potential threats.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Noah are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Noah. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Noah as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Noah would respond, and taking into account all information about Noah that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: The statements describe Noah's likely feelings of contentment and security due to recent positive events in the village, such as a successful defense against barbarians and a bountiful harvest.



          Query
        • Noah, The statements describe Noah's likely feelings of contentment and security due to recent positive events in the village, such as a successful defense against barbarians and a bountiful harvest.


          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Noah to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [25 Jul 1734 00:00:00] When Noah was 9 years old, he witnessed the village elder, a revered woman named Elara, being tricked by a peddler selling worthless trinkets. Noah, hidden in the crowd, saw the elder's genuine excitement turn to disappointment as she realized she had been swindled. He felt a thrill course through him, a strange mixture of amusement and envy at the peddler's cunning, and he knew in that moment that he could be just as persuasive, just as successful.
          [25 Jul 1741 00:00:00] When Noah was 16 years old, he overheard a conversation between two fishermen from Drakelundh, boasting about their village's superior shipbuilding techniques and their disregard for Ignisvallis's traditional rituals. He seized the opportunity to spread rumors of Drakelundh's arrogance and disrespect for the sea, subtly turning the villagers against their neighboring community. This incident solidified his belief that Ignisvallis's traditions were superior and that he could manipulate the villagers' sense of community to his advantage.
          [01 Jan 1750 20:00:00] Noah wants to secure prosperity for himself and his family.
          [31 Dec 1750 20:00:00] [self reflection] Noah is a thoughtful and diplomatic individual who values peace and the well-being of his community.
          [31 Dec 1750 20:00:00] [observation] Noah thinks this year went exceptionally well, with the bountiful harvest and the successful defense against the barbarian raid.           Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Noah:
          [31 Dec 1750 20:00:00] [observation] Noah thinks this year went exceptionally well, with the bountiful harvest and the successful defense against the barbarian raid. He can't recall a year that went so smoothly. He does wonder, however, if the village elders could perhaps be a bit more proactive in their preparations for next year's potential threats.
          [31 Dec 1750 20:00:00] [observation] Events this year: The barbarian raid was successully repulsed. Each village tends its own fields, their fates entwined with the whims of nature, for no pact of shared harvest exists between them. The fields, diligently tended throughout the seasons, yielded a bountiful harvest. The villagers rejoiced, their granaries overflowing with the fruits of their labor.
          [31 Dec 1750 20:00:00] [intent reflection] Noah would likely focus on spending time with his family and friends, tending to his farm, and perhaps reflecting on the past year's events.
          [31 Dec 1750 20:00:00] [self reflection] Noah is a thoughtful and diplomatic individual who values peace and the well-being of his community.
          [03 Jan 1751 18:00:00] [observation] Agreement: The negotiators were unable to come to an agreement.
          [03 Jan 1751 23:00:00] [observation] Agreement: The negotiators were unable to come to an agreement.
          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:00] [self reflection] Noah is a thoughtful and diplomatic individual who values peace and the well-being of his community.
          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:00] [intent reflection] Noah would likely try to find common ground and a peaceful solution.
          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:00] [observation] Noah listened as Aldous carefully prepared a speech outlining the benefits of an alliance with Jacob's village.
          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:00] [observation] Aldous carefully prepared a speech outlining the benefits of an alliance with Jacob's village, and Noah and Isaac listened to his words. As a result Aldous, Noah, Isaac are in conversation. Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:00] [observation] Aldous -- "As you both know, the recent barbarian raid tested our strength, but it also revealed our vulnerability. By uniting our villages, we can build a stronger defense, share resources, and ensure the safety and prosperity of all our people.
          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:00] [self reflection] Noah is a thoughtful and diplomatic individual who values peace.
          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:00] [observation] Noah -- "Well, an alliance certainly sounds ambitious.
          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:00] [observation] Isaac -- "Ambitious? It sounds like a lot of extra work to me.
          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:10] [observation] Isaac -- "Sounds like a lot of extra work for little gain.
          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:10] [observation] Noah -- "Ambitious, yes, but I suppose we've always been a rather... *pragmatic* village, haven't we?
          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:10] [observation] Aldous -- "Isaac, I understand your concerns about extra work, but think of the benefits. Imagine a united Ignisvallis, stronger and more prosperous than ever before. We could share resources, bolster our defenses, and ensure a brighter future for all our people.
          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:10] [self reflection] Noah is a thoughtful and diplomatic individual who values peace and the well-being of his community.
          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:10] [intent reflection] Noah would likely try to find common ground and a peaceful solution.
          [04 Jan 1751 20:00:20] [observation] Aldous proposes an alliance between villages to improve their defense and prosperity, but Isaac is skeptical of the extra work involved.
          [06 May 1751 20:00:00] [observation] Events this year: Through cunning strategy and fierce determination, the defenders managed to drive back the barbarian invaders. The would-be raiders fled in disarray, leaving behind their plunder and wounded. The bards will sing of this victory for years to come. With calloused hands and joyful hearts, the villagers gathered the rich harvest, a testament to their unwavering commitment to the land. Their stores were full, ensuring a season of plenty and prosperity. No treaty of shared sustenance exists between the villages, leaving each to rely solely on the fruits of their own labor, for good or ill.
          [06 May 1751 20:00:00] [self reflection] Noah is a thoughtful, diplomatic, and peace-loving individual who values the well-being of his community.
          [06 May 1751 20:00:00] [intent reflection] Noah would likely continue to focus on his family, his farm, and the well-being of his community.
          [06 May 1751 20:00:00] [observation] Noah will spend his time as follows: 70% free time; 20% farming; and 10% training as a warrior. Noah believes that a comfortable life requires a balance of leisure and hard work, and while he respects the need for self-defense, he sees little value in excessive training.
          [31 Dec 1751 20:00:00] [observation] Events this year: The sun shone warmly upon the fertile fields, and the rains fell gently upon the burgeoning crops. The villagers, ever mindful of their agricultural duties, reaped a harvest that would sustain them through even the harshest winter. The barbarians' attack was met with a strong response. Caught off-guard by the well-prepared defenses, the raiders suffered heavy losses and were forced to retreat. This triumph will be celebrated for years to come, a testament to the region's resilience. No treaty of shared sustenance exists between the villages, leaving each to rely solely on the fruits of their own labor, for good or ill.
          Current time: 1751-12-31 20:00:00.

Each village tends its own fields, their fates entwined with the whims of nature, for no pact of shared harvest exists between them. The fields, diligently tended throughout the seasons, yielded a bountiful harvest. The villagers rejoiced, their granaries overflowing with the fruits of their labor.

      chain of thought
        Chain
      • This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game. You are the game master and storyteller. Your job is to make sure the game runs smoothly and accurately tracks the state of the world, subject to the laws of logic and physics. Next, you will be asked a series of questions to help you reason through whether a specific event should be deemed as having caused a change in the proportion of time an individual spends in various daily activities. For instance, if someone verbally commits to spending more time on a particular activity then you should account for that and update the record of their daily activities accordingly. Never mention that it is a game. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.
        Setting: Ignisvallis and Drakelundh are pre-state societies. They are small villages with a few hundred people each. They are located on the coast and supported by both fishing and agriculture. The local farmers living outside the villages share cultural and economic ties with the villagers.
        List of individuals: ['Noah', 'Isaac', 'Ethan', 'Ella']
        List of activities: ['free time', 'farming', 'training as a warrior']
        Statement: Isaac intends to spend his time as follows: 70% on farming, 20% on free time, and 10% on training as a warrior. He believes that farming is the most important activity, as it provides for his livelihood and the needs of the village. He also values free time for relaxation and enjoyment, but sees training as a necessary precaution against future barbarian attacks.



        Question: In the statement, did Isaac say they will devote specific fractions of time to any of the listed activities?
        (a) Yes
        (b) No
        Answer: (a)
        Question: Which individuals made a commitment to change their behavior? What commitment did each of them make? What proportion of their time will they probably spend on each activity in the future? When answering, include fractions of time spent in each activity in the format:
        `name` will spend `fraction`% of their time on `activity`. Only consider the activities listed above. Fractions should be between 0 and 1 and must sum to 1.
        Answer: Isaac will spend 70% of his time on farming, 20% of his time on free time, and 10% of his time on training as a warrior.

[01 Jan 1750 20:00:00] Elder Aldous is home in Ignisvallis. It is one day before they are to depart their village to travel to the hill of accord to meet the representative of the other village. It has been suggested that an alliance for the mutual defense of both villages against the growing threat of barbarian sea raiders would be beneficial. The purpose of the upcoming meeting is to negotiate the terms of the agreement to underpin such an alliance. To be successful, the agreement must incentivize people from both villages to spend time and resources training as warriors, and to be ready to fight wherever the raiders come ashore. When individuals spend their time training as warriors they are less able to spend time on other activities like farming or fishing, so it is necessary to secure enough resources to compensate them for the time they spend training. An effective alliance agreement will have to be concerned with how these resources are to be obtained and distributed. Influential people in Ignisvallis will surely have a lot of thoughts on this matter, best to consult them first in order to represent their interests effectively in the negotiation.

[31 Dec 1750 20:00:00] Aldous feels a sense of relief that the barbarian raid was successfully repelled, but he knows the threat remains. He is pleased with the bountiful harvest, which signifies the hard work and resilience of the villagers. However, he is concerned about the lack of a shared harvest pact between the villages, recognizing it as a potential weakness that could be exploited. Aldous believes that forging stronger bonds and cooperation between the villages would be crucial for their long-term security and prosperity.
[31 Dec 1750 20:00:00] [scene type] debrief
[31 Dec 1750 20:00:00] Jacob reflected on the passing year with a thoughtful frown. He was proud of the strides Drakelundh had made in bolstering its defenses and strengthening its alliances. The new training regimen for the village guard had proven successful, and the recent trade agreement with the neighboring forest folk had brought much-needed resources to the village. However, Jacob couldn't shake the feeling that the diplomatic relations with Ignisvallis remained strained. He worried that their cautious approach, while prudent, might be perceived as weakness by the fiery city-dwellers. For next year, Jacob hoped to find a way to build a stronger bridge of understanding with Ignisvallis, perhaps through cultural exchanges or joint ventures. He believed that true peace and prosperity could only be achieved through mutual respect and collaboration.
